The Sydney Morning Herald Conflict grows: A Free Syrian Army rebel shouts after hitting a tank in Saraqib city with a rocket propelled grenade as fears grow fighting could spread to other countries. Photo: Getty Images INTERNATIONAL efforts to resolve the Syria crisis are in disarray, with the regime of Bashar al-Assad failing to meet the deadline for the withdrawal of troops who have killed more than 9000 civilians and opposition soldiers since the country's uprising began just over a year ago. From Homs, Daraa and Idlib, Damascus to Aleppo, the list of the dead has grown longer as Dr Assad's ferocious attack on his people escalated with the approaching deadline - spilling over into neighbouring Turkey and Lebanon. As the deadline passed, China said it supported the proposals of United Nations special envoy to Syria Kofi Annan for ending the violence. Foreign Ministry spokesman Liu Weimin said at a briefing yesterday in Beijing that China hoped that the Syrian government and other parties involved in a year-long conflict could commit to a peace plan crafted by Mr Annan. Russia yesterday called on Syria to implement the troop pullout. ''We demand from our Syrian colleagues to rigorously implement the Annan plan,'' Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said after talks in Moscow with Syrian Foreign Minister Walid Al-Muallem. Mr Lavrov said Syria had not been active enough in withdrawing its army units. Syrian opposition groups must also accept an immediate ceasefire, Mr Lavrov said. The border village of Salama, north of Aleppo, was raided by tanks amid heavy machinegun fire targeting those trying to flee to Turkey, the Syrian Network for Human Rights reported. Syrian gunmen also fired at refugees crossing the border, and into the Turkish refugee camp in Kilis, killing two Syrians and wounding 15 others, including Turkish staff at the camp. The attack, which drew fierce condemnation from Turkey and from the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, has raised fears that the Syrian conflict might draw in other countries in the volatile region. The camp is metres from the border and home to about 8000 of the 24,000 refugees who have crossed into Turkey. Mr Annan's team is expected to visit the camp in coming days. ''Syrian citizens who took refuge in our country from the brutality of the current regime in Syria are under Turkey's full protection,'' the Turkish Foreign Ministry said in a statement. ''We will certainly take necessary measures if such incidents reoccur.'' In Lebanon, a cameraman was killed when Syrian forces fired across the border into the Wadi Khaled area in the country's north. Lebanese security officials said gunfire came from the nearby Syrian village of Armouta. It is no surprise that President Assad reneged on his agreement to implement the Annan-negotiated peace plan, said Rami Khouri, the director of the Issam Fares Institute for Public Policy and International Affairs at the American University of Beirut. 6 people are reading this now.
